choices.text: Call her fasting and give loading dose of 75 gram oral glucose and check blood glucose after 2 hours
Call her without fasting and and administer her loading dose 75 gram oral glucose and check blood glucose after 2 hours
Call her fasting and administer her 100 gm oral glucose and check blood glucose after 2 hours

questions.text: A patient came to the ANC OPD at 26 weeks gestation. She is a known case of hypothyroidism, and has family history of type 2 DM on paternal side. Which of the following tests will you do as per Indian guidelines ?
questions.solution:
Screening test for GDM in pregnancy


Preferred test in India is DIPSI

HbA1C is never used for screening test. It is used to differentiate between overt diabetes mellitus and GDM


Reference: J.B. sharma obstetrics 3/edition, page number:548

questions.text: What is the dose of Misoprostol used for medical abortion?
questions.solution:
Misoprostol Dosage and Route for Various Indications


  • Contraindications: Misoprostol is contraindicated in certain situations, such as pregnancy after a previous cesarean section, active internal bleeding, and severe renal or hepatic impairment.
  • Side effects: Misoprostol can cause side effects such as cramping, bleeding, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
  • Monitoring: Regular monitoring of vital signs and fetal well-being is essential during misoprostol use.

Reference: FIGO Guidelines, 2017

choices.text: Low serum calcium levels and high serum magnesium levels
Low serum glucose levels and high serum bilirubin levels
High serum magnesium levels and high serum bilirubin levels
Low serum glucose levels and low red blood cell mass

questions.text: An infant was born to a mother with diabetes. Which of the following will you expect to occur to the infant ?
questions.solution:
Metabolic changes in neonates of diabetic mother

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Polycythemia
  • Hyperbilirubinemia

Other disorders in neonates

  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Increased red cell mass → hyperviscosity in blood
  • macrosomia

Congenital disorders


Reference : J.B. sharma obstetrics 3/edition, page number:548

questions.text: A resident doctor was delivering a 30 year old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus. After delivery of the head, difficulty was felt while delivering the shoulder. Which of the following maneuvers will not help in delivery of the baby in such condition ?
questions.solution:
Shoulder dystocia i.e difficulty in delivery of the shoulder of baby is a common complication in gestational diabetes and following are the maneuvers in shoulder dystocia :

Initial steps

  • Call for help
  • Extend episiotomy
  • Hyperflex legs and give suprapubic pressure (Mc roberts maneuver)

Mc roberts maneuver


Rubins maneuver


Woods corkscrew maneuver


Forceful delivery of posterior arm


Gaskin maneuver (Roll over patient on all 4 limbs)


Zavanelli maneuver: If none of the above maneuvers work then one will have to push the fetal head inside and deliver by c section.

Reference: D.C. Dutta textbook of obstetrics, 9/edition, chapter 27, page number:380

questions.text: Till what time can suction evacuation be done?
questions.solution:
Suction and evacuation is a method of MTP in the 1st trimester of pregnancy(i.e till 12 weeks)

Methods of MTP:

choices.text: Opinion of 1 RMP required till 12 weeks and 2 RMP between 12 and 24 weeks
Fine and or imprisonment in cases when there is breach of confidentiality of women undergoing MTP
Upper limit of termination has been changed to 24 weeks
MTP beyond 24 weeks requires the opinion of a medical board

questions.text: According to the recent MTP act 2021 amendments, which of the following is not true?
questions.solution:
Changes in MTP act :


  • Increases the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women, including survivors of rape, victims of incest and other vulnerable women (differently abled women, minors, among others)

NOTE :

  • The Act allows abortion after 24 weeks only in cases where a Medical Board diagnoses substantial foetal abnormalities.
  • This implies that for a case requiring abortion due to rape, that exceeds 24-weeks, the only recourse remains through a Writ Petition.

Reference : J.B. sharma obstetrics 3/edition, page number:131

choices.text: MD degree in Obstetrics and Gynecology
6 months of house surgeon ship in gynecology and obstetrics
Assisted 20 MTPs in a government hospital
Experience in any hospital for at least 1 year in field of obstetrics and gynecology

questions.text: Who has not been designated as a RMP to perform MTP by the law ?
questions.solution:
Who can perform MTP ?

  1. Postgraduate degree or diploma in gynecology and obstetrics(Option A ruled out)
  2. Six months of house surgeonship in gynecology and obstetrics(Option B ruled out)
  3. Experience in any hospital of over 1 year in the field of gynecology and obstetrics(Option D ruled out)
  4. Assisted in performing 25 MTPs in a government hospital or a recognised training institute

Reference : J.B. sharma obstetrics 3/edition, page number:131

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for diagnosis of pre eclampsia with severe features in pregnancy ?
questions.solution:
Preeclampsia with severe features

questions.text: A 12 weeks POG patient presents with grape like vesicles coming out per vaginum. USG scan is shown below. The hormone responsible for this condition is?
questions.solution:
This is a case of complete molar pregnancy.

Molar pregnancy is a rare condition that occurs when a non-cancerous tumor forms in the uterus instead of a normal pregnancy. This tumor develops from abnormal placental tissue.

Types of molar pregnancy:

  • Complete molar pregnancy: In this type, the entire fetus is replaced by a mass of abnormal tissue.
  • Partial molar pregnancy: In this type, some fetal tissue may be present, but it is not viable.

Symptoms:

  • Vaginal bleeding: This can range from light spotting to heavy bleeding.
  • Abdominal pain or cramping
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Rapidly growing uterus
  • Preeclampsia

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound: An ultrasound exam can help visualize the abnormal mass in the uterus.
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) test: A blood test to measure hCG levels, which are often elevated in molar pregnancies.

Treatment:

  • Dilation and curettage (D&C): A surgical procedure to remove the molar tissue from the uterus.
  • Chemotherapy: In some cases, chemotherapy may be necessary to treat any remaining abnormal tissue.
  • Follow-up: Regular follow-up is important to monitor for recurrence.

Complications:

  • Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD): A rare condition that can develop after a molar pregnancy.
  • Infertility

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics 9th edition, Page number. 225

questions.text: Match the magnesium levels with effects
questions.solution:
Magnesium sulfate is known to have short therapeutic window and hence therapeutic monitoring is important during administering Pritchard regimen for eclampsia in order to prevent toxicity.

Three fold monitoring needs to be done : patellar reflexes, urine output, and respiratory rate


Reference : J.B. Sharma obstetrics 3/edition, page number:451

questions.text:
A 26 year old primigravida with 37 weeks pregnancy with blood pressure of 160/100 mmhg and urine albumin of +3 and platelet count of 90000/cumm comes to labour room. What is the Management ?
1. Labour induction
2. Emergency c section
3. Betamethasone coverage
4. Magnesium sulphate administration
5. Labetalol
questions.solution:
Low platelet count and blood pressure more than 160 mmhg is suggestive of pre eclampsia with severe features. Thus delivery needs to be conducted.

In absence of any obstetric indication, vaginal delivery is preferred through labour induction.(Statement 1)

Magnesium sulphate is given for severe features to prevent impending eclampsia.(Statement 4)

Labetalol is given to control blood pressure.(Statement 5)

There are no grounds to do emergency c section(Statement 2)or giving corticosteroids considering her gestational age(Statement 3)

Reference : J.B. Sharma obstetrics 3/edition, page number:451

questions.text: A second gravida female came to labour room with 36 week 2 days pregnancy with complain of bleeding per vaginum. The patient had abdominal pain for 4 hours. The uterus was tonically contracted. On examination the uterus was found to be reaching upto xiphisternum. Based on the above facts which is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Abruptio placenta:

Defined as antepartum hemorrhage occurring due to abrupt(premature separation of placenta from placental bed).

Decidual bleeding leads to release of thromboplastin which induces uterine contractions

Clinical features :

  1. Uterine contractions present
  2. Bleeding per vaginum
  3. Uterus tense, tender.
  4. Uterus more than gestational age if hemorrhage is concealed
  5. Hypertension
  6. Fetal distress or IUFD

Types of abruptio placenta

  • Revealed hemorrhage : frank bleeding per vaginum. Pallor corresponds to bleeding. Uterine size corresponds to POG
  • Concealed hemorrhage : frank bleeding may not be seen. Pallor more than the bleeding per vaginum. Uterine size more than POG

Complication : DIC, maternal death, fetal death.

Couvellaire uterus : blood exsanguinates into the myometrium and serosa of uterus leading to couvellaire uterus. The uterus is at high risk of atonic PPH. there may be requirement of obstetric hysterectomy

Reference : J.B. Sharma obstetrics 3/edition, page number:433

questions.text:
A 23 year old primigravida came to the labour room with 35 weeks 3 days of pregnancy with complain of bleeding per vaginum with passage of clots. She had associated complain of abdominal pain for 2 hours. After assessing the vitals and the fetal heart, a decision was made to go for cesarean section for the delivery. Intraoperatively the uterus was found to have bluish discolouration. Which if the following are characteristics of the diagnosis made for the condition?
1. Systolic blood pressure 160 mmhg
2. USG suggestive of hematoma behind the placenta
3. +3 proteinuria on urine albumin reagent strip
4. Dark maroon liquor on amniotom
5. USG suggestive of placental edge 1 cm from internal OS
6. Tonically contracted uteru
7. Painless bleeding
8. Placental mass seen on per speculum examination
questions.solution:
The diagnosis made is abruptio placenta


Reference : J.B. Sharma obstetrics 3/edition, page number:433

questions.text: In cases of suspected ectopic pregnancy, what is the best indicator?
questions.solution:
Beta HCG is an indicator for ectopic pregnancy.

In cases of Pregnancy of Unknown Location (PUL)-where pregnancy is confirmed, but no gestational sac is visible in the uterus or ectopic locations on ultrasound-the human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) approach is a critical method for determining the location and viability of the pregnancy. Here's how it works:

  1. Initial hCG Measurement
  • A baseline serum hCG level is taken to assess if the hormone level aligns with a detectable intrauterine pregnancy.
  • Typically, an intrauterine pregnancy should be visible on transvaginal ultrasound if hCG levels are ≥1500-2000 mIU/mL.
  1. Serial hCG Testing (48-hour Interval)
  • Serial hCG measurements are taken every 48 hours to observe the trend in hCG levels.
  • In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, hCG levels should increase by at least 53% every 48 hours in early pregnancy.
  • If hCG levels rise inadequately, remain static, or fall, it may indicate an abnormal pregnancy or an ectopic pregnancy.
  1. Interpreting hCG Trends
  • Rising hCG (>53% increase in 48 hours): Suggests an intrauterine pregnancy, though it may not rule out an ectopic pregnancy. Additional ultrasounds and clinical correlation are recommended.
  • Plateauing or slow-rising hCG: May indicate an ectopic pregnancy or an early pregnancy loss. Close monitoring and further testing are often necessary.
  • Declining hCG: Suggests a non-viable pregnancy, either resolving spontaneously or as an ectopic pregnancy.
  1. Additional Testing Based on hCG Trends
  • If hCG levels suggest an ectopic pregnancy (e.g., low rise or plateau), a repeat ultrasound or laparoscopic assessment may be performed.
  • If hCG continues to fall, expectant management is often appropriate, but persistent monitoring is essential to rule out ectopic risks.

This hCG-based approach, combined with ultrasound and clinical findings, aids in managing PUL effectively and determining appropriate next steps.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page number. 580
